Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Untangling the Deep Genealogy of Microbial Dark Matter
Award.AbstractNarration:
Breakthrough technology enabling rapid sequencing of whole genomes from single cells, will be used in this project to unlock secrets of life's early evolution and genealogy. Prior to this breakthrough, many of life's earliest diverging lineages could not be analyzed because they cannot be grown in laboratory cultures. This unculturable "Microbial Dark Matter" (MDM) within the groups Bacteria and Archaea constitutes the majority of biological species diversity and biological mass on Earth, and this can now be brought to light by the sequencing of single amplified genomes (SAGs). In this unprecedented research project, many new genomes, encoding the blueprints for disparate organisms, can and will be analyzed to illuminate (1) the genealogy of these ancient microbial species, (2) the relative timing of their origins, and (3) the role that horizontal gene transfer among distant relatives may have played in the origins of new species and novel ways of living. Further, extensive MDM sampling will be done from unexplored subterranean environments around the world, enhancing the discovery and understanding of life forms that are new to science.

A team of collaborating scientists will analyze over 100 MDM-rich field samples, collected from multiple study sites, including Precambrian shield environments from the Kaapvaall Craton of South Africa, a Precambrian metamorphic complex accessed via the Sanford Underground Research Facility in South Dakota, and fault-associated springs associated with Tertiary volcanic areas and Cambrian-aged sedimentary rocks of the Death Valley Regional Flow System in Nevada. Extensive contextual information (environmental and biological metadata) will also be incorporated in these sampling efforts. The research tasks begin with the collection of field samples and metadata from sites known or suspected to contain a high proportion of MDM. Then, the microbial community composition within the collected samples is surveyed by sequencing their small sub-unit (SSU) rRNA gene iTags. Based on the iTag data, 20 samples that best meet the objectives of this project are selected, and 12,600 single amplified genomes (SAGs) from them will be sequenced. The SAGs will then be identified by their SSU rRNA genes, and 800 MDM SAGs that best meet the objectives of this project will be further annotated, aligned and combined with various publicly-available data sets for use in detailed, statistical phylogenetic reconstruction of a comprehensive genealogy for Bacteria and Archaea. The genealogical inferences, in combination with other data layers important to understanding MDM evolution (including geochemical, geospatial, microbial community composition, and microbial physiology data) will be compiled and used in addressing the project's general evolutionary questions, as noted above. Analyses will also address the potential for the deep subsurface environments of Earth to serve as a repository for the early evolutionary history of Bacteria and Archaea. This project leverages an existing major award to the researchers through the DOE Joint Genome Institute to cover sequencing costs. The project has a very rich educational and outreach component, geared toward research experiences for undergraduate and graduate students, postdoctoral researchers and high school teachers. Engaging outreach activities and media designed for the general public are also planned. Further, the laboratory and computational tools and the massive genomic data produced by this project will provide a major resource to the broad research community and, potentially, to the biotechnology industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Breakthrough technology, enabling rapid sequencing of whole genomes from single microbial cells, has been used by this project to unlock secrets of life's evolution and genealogy. Prior to this, the genetic capacity of the majority of microbial lineages could not be analyzed because they cannot be grown in the laboratory with available approaches. This unculturable "Microbial Dark Matter" (MDM), within the Bacteria and Archaea, constitutes the majority of biological species diversity on Earth and can now be brought to light by the sequencing of single amplified genomes (SAGs). In this research project, new genomes, encoding the blueprints for disparate organisms (e.g., the Rokubacteria [Becraft et al., 2017] and Kiritimatiellae [Sackett 2019]), were analyzed to illuminate the genealogy of potentially ancient microbial lineages. To achieve project objectives, extensive MDM sampling, supplemented with environmental data, was conducted from little-explored subterranean environments in North America and South Africa. Our subgroup was part of a larger team which analyzed dozens of MDM-rich field samples from multiple study sites, including: Precambrian shield environments from the Kaapvaal Craton of South Africa (led by T.C. Onstott), a Precambrian metamorphic complex accessed via the Sanford Underground Research Facility (SURF) in South Dakota, USA, and fault-associated springs and boreholes associated with Tertiary volcanic and Cambrian-aged sedimentary rocks of the Death Valley Regional Flow System (DVRFS) in Nevada and California, USA.

Our research tasks began with the collection of water samples, and corresponding metadata, from sites known to contain a high proportion of MDM. Microbial community composition was surveyed by small subunit (SSU) rRNA gene iTag libraries. Based on the iTag data, 20 samples were selected for molecular analysis. Ultimately ~12,600 SAGs were screened and >2,000 sequenced through Bigelow Lab and the DOE Joint Genome Institute (JGI). Individual SAGs were identified by their SSU rRNA genes, and ~800 MDM SAGs were annotated, aligned and combined with public datasets for genomic reconstruction of select lineages. These genealogical inferences, in combination with other data layers important to understanding MDM evolution (including geochemical, geospatial, microbial community composition, and microbial physiology) are being compiled. This project leverages an existing major award through the JGI to extend sequencing costs. The project has had a rich educational and outreach component, geared toward research experiences for undergraduate and graduate students, postdoctoral researchers and high school teachers.

Our subgroup specifically has trained two Ph.D. young investigators, one graduate student, and a minority undergraduate student (National ASM Fellowship winner). Outreach/media activity included the filming of sampling at a high-flow spring and inclusion of the footage in a segment of the popular Nevada Public Television program, Outdoor Nevada. Our main contribution was front-loaded, mostly into the first two years of the project. We performed 16S rRNA gene surveys (Illumina [iTag] libraries) to assist with selection of MDM-rich samples. Samples utilized in Becraft et al. (2017), which focused on the novel phylum Rokubacteria, included three separate pumped water samples from a well in Oasis Valley, NV, the outlet of the largest-flow spring in the Mojave Desert (Crystal Spring in Ash Meadows, NV) and SURF wall seeps. Additional samples include a sentinel well in Central Nevada volcanic rocks (PM-3), a high-elevation mountain block spring from the Spring Mountains outside of Las Vegas (Cold Creek), Devils Hole, and other springs from the Ash Meadows System in Nevada?s Amargosa Valley, and a deep borehole near Death Valley (BLM-1). Relevant publications describe the microbial biogeochemistry of MDM from Devils Hole and BLM-1 (Sackett et al., 2018; Sackett, 2018) including the Kiritimatiellae class of Verrucomicrobiota (Sackett, 2019).

Sackett, J.D. (2018). Prokaryotic diversity and aqueous geochemistry of subsurface environments of the Death Valley Regional Flow System. Ph.D. Dissertation. University of Nevada Las Vegas.

Sackett, J.D., D.C. Huerta, B.R. Kruger, S.D. Hamilton-Brehm and D. P. Moser (2018). A comparative study of prokaryotic diversity and physicochemical characteristics of Devils Hole and the Ash Meadows Fish Conservation Facility, a constructed analog. PloS one 13(3),e0194404.
